data.name: paragraph
data.body: There are two types of charges: positive and negative. Positive and negative charges can cancel each other out.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Like charges repel whereas unlike charges attract each other.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When charged bodies are very small compared to the distances between them, they are treated as point charges. All the charge is considered concentrated at one point.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Charges add up algebraically, similar to real numbers. If a system has charges \( q_1 \) and \( q_2 \), the total charge is \( q_1 + q_2 \). Charges have magnitude, but unlike mass, they can be positive or negative.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Charges are not created or destroyed when bodies are charged by rubbing. In an isolated system of charged bodies, charges may be redistributed, but the total charge remains constant.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: All free charges are integral multiples of a basic unit denoted by \( e \). Charge on a body is given by \( q = ne \), where \( n \) is an integer. The basic unit of charge is the charge carried by an electron or proton. In SI units, 1 Coulomb (C) is the charge flowing through a wire in 1 second with a current of 1 Ampere. The value of the basic unit of charge (\( e \)) is \( 1.602192 \times 10^{-19} \). Charges can be in steps of \( e \), and observable charges are integral multiples of \( e \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Think of electric charges like coins. You have coins of different values (positive and negative), and when you add them up, the total is like the total charge in a system. When you transfer coins between pockets, the total value doesn't change. This is like the conservation of charge in electric systems.
